atAGlance.mustRegister: Adults convicted of qualifying sexual offenses (or out-of-state/federal equivalents) who live, work, or study in Florida must register. Core duties and definitions are in Fla. Stat. §943.0435 (sexual offenders) and §775.21 (sexual predators).
atAGlance.initialDeadline: Within 48 hours of establishing residence, employment, or school in FL, report in person to the sheriff (see §943.0435; predators see §775.21).
atAGlance.verificationCadence: Sexual offenders: re-register twice per year (birth month + 6 months later). Some offenses require quarterly re-registration. Sexual predators: quarterly. (See FDLE FAQ; §943.0435(14); §775.21(8)).
atAGlance.primaryMethod: In-person with county sheriff; additional updates via FDLE online system where allowed. Driver license/ID update required within 48 hours after initial registration (see DHSMV/FDLE notice).
topGotchas: “Temporary residence” includes vacation/business stays of 3 or more days in the aggregate in a calendar year—this can trigger registration (see definition in §775.21(2)).
Transient (homeless) offenders must report in person every 30 days while transient (see §943.0435; predators: §775.21).
Driver license/ID must display “SEXUAL PREDATOR” or “943.0435, F.S.” designation and be obtained/updated within 48 hours after initial registration (see FDLE/DHSMV notice).

whoMustRegister: Persons meeting the ‘sexual offender’ definition in §943.0435 or designated as ‘sexual predator’ under §775.21, including those with out-of-state, federal, or military convictions that are similar or who were required to register elsewhere.
deadlinesReporting: Initial in-person registration with the sheriff within 48 hours of establishing a permanent, temporary, or transient residence; employment; or school in FL (see §943.0435).
Obtain/renew FL driver license or ID card with required designation within 48 hours after initial registration (see FDLE/DHSMV notice).

Report changes (name, residence—permanent/temporary/transient, employment, school, vehicles, phone numbers, emails, internet identifiers) within 48 hours (some items may be via FDLE online system) (see §943.0435).
Transient status: after establishing, report every 30 days in person while transient (see §943.0435; predators see §775.21).
verificationInPerson: Sexual offenders: reregister twice per year (birth month and the 6th month thereafter) or quarterly for specified offenses (see FDLE FAQ; §943.0435(14)).
Sexual predators: quarterly reregistration (see §775.21(8)).
Sheriff sets reporting days/times; bring ID and any updated info (vehicles, online identifiers, etc.).
residencyPresence: Statewide residency restriction: certain persons whose victim was < 16 may not reside within 1,000 feet of any school, child care facility, park, or playground (see §775.215). Local ordinances may impose stricter distances.
employmentEducationInternet: Report employment and post-secondary school info and changes within 48 hours (see §943.0435).
Register emails and internet identifiers (and corresponding site/app) within 48 hours of use or change (see §943.0435).
Job/volunteer restrictions may apply via supervision terms or local rules even if not set by statewide statute.
publicWebsiteExposure: FDLE publicly lists offenders/predators with photo, addresses, and identifiers; listings generally remain even after moving out of state (see FDLE FAQ).
Neighborhood search and other tools are available (see FDLE search).
travelInterstate: If moving out of FL, notify and complete required updates before departure; if plans change and you remain in FL, you must report in person within 48 hours (see historical §943.0435(8); current duties in §943.0435).
International travel: provide 21-day advance notice under International Megan’s Law via your registering agency (coordinate with your sheriff/FDLE).
visitingTraveling: “Temporary residence” includes vacation/business stays of 3 or more days in the aggregate in a calendar year; reaching that threshold triggers Florida registration duties (see definition cross-referenced in §775.21(2) and FDLE guidance).
Hotel nights count toward the 3-day aggregate threshold. Keep proof of dates.
Your home state may still require pre-travel notice even for short trips—comply with both states’ rules.
complianceEnforcement: Failure to register/reregister/update as required is a felony (penalties vary by subsection and priors). Noncompliance while transient can trigger separate violations (see §943.0435).
reliefPaths: Florida registration is generally for life. Some limited relief may exist only if the underlying conviction is vacated/pardoned or criteria met for removal under specific provisions (see FDLE FAQ).
specialPopulations: Transient (homeless): must report every 30 days while transient (see §943.0435; predators see §775.21).
Juveniles tried as adults may be required to register; juvenile adjudications follow separate statutes not covered here.
costs: Florida statutes do not set a uniform state registration fee; standard DHSMV fees apply for the required driver license/ID with designation. Some counties may assess administrative fees—confirm locally.

newArrivalChecklist: Within 48 hours of arrival to live, work, or study: register in person with the county sheriff (see §943.0435).
Within 48 hours after initial registration: obtain or update your FL driver license/ID with required designation (see FDLE/DHSMV notice).
Calendar your reregistration months (birth month and 6 months later; or quarterly if applicable) and set reminders.
movingOutChecklist: Notify the sheriff/FDLE of your move and comply with destination state registration.
If plans change and you remain in FL, report in person within 48 hours to update your intent (see historical §943.0435(8)).
Keep stamped/dated proof of all submissions.

citations: Fla. Stat. §943.0435 (sexual offenders: registration, updates, reregistration)
Fla. Stat. §775.21 (sexual predators; quarterly; definitions incl. temporary residence)
Fla. Stat. §775.215 (statewide 1,000-ft residency restriction for certain offenses with victims < 16)
FDLE FAQ: lifetime registration; biannual vs. quarterly reregistration
FDLE/DHSMV notice: 48-hour driver license/ID requirement & designations

summary: Florida’s timelines are short and the definition of “temporary residence” is broad—short trips can trigger registration.
Plan for two in-person check-ins per year (or quarterly depending on your offense/designation).
watchOuts: The 3-day aggregate rule for temporary residence can sneak up on vacationers and business travelers.
Driver license/ID update is due within 48 hours after initial registration and must carry a designation.
atAGlance.validationNote: Confirmed with §943.0435, §775.21, FDLE FAQ, and DHSMV/FDLE notice. Content validated with the help of AI; please contact SOLAR if you find something outdated.

summary: Register in person with the sheriff within 48 hours of establishing residence, job, or school in Florida.
Update changes (address types, name, employment, school, vehicles, phones, emails, internet IDs) within 48 hours.
watchOuts: Transient status requires in-person reporting every 30 days until you establish a permanent/temporary residence.
Missing the DHSMV ID update after initial registration can itself be charged.
deadlinesReporting.validationNote: See §943.0435 and FDLE/DHSMV notice.

summary: You’ll reregister either twice yearly or quarterly in person, based on offense/designation.
Sheriffs set reporting windows—show up with ID and any changes ready to file.
watchOuts: Mark your calendar for your birth-month window and the 6-month mark (or every 3 months).
Keep stamped receipts; each missed window can be a separate charge.
verificationInPerson.validationNote: Derived from §943.0435(14) and FDLE FAQ; predators see §775.21(8).

summary: Vacation or business in Florida totaling 3+ days in a calendar year counts as a temporary residence and can trigger in-state registration.
Hotel nights count; keep clear records of dates.
watchOuts: Your home state may require travel notice before you leave—comply with both states.
If your plans change (you stay longer or decide to move), re-contact the sheriff immediately to stay compliant.
visitingTraveling.validationNote: “Temporary residence” definition referenced in §775.21(2) and reflected in FDLE practice.

summary: If the victim was under 16 for certain listed offenses, Florida law bars living within 1,000 feet of schools, parks, playgrounds, or child-care facilities.
watchOuts: Measure property-line to property-line; mapping tools can help but confirm with local law enforcement.
Leases can be voided if found non-compliant—get a compliance check before signing.

summary: Report job and school details within 48 hours; register emails and internet identifiers within 48 hours of use/change.
Schools and many employers will verify status; proactively confirm your obligations before starting.
watchOuts: If self-employed or gig-based, you must still report the business and locations.
Universities consider ‘enrolled’ broadly—course adds/drops and campus changes can trigger updates.
employmentEducationInternet.validationNote: Reporting scope and timelines in §943.0435.

summary: Failure to register/reregister/update within the windows can be charged as a felony.
Non-compliance can affect eligibility for relief elsewhere and may stack if repeated.
watchOuts: Keep dated/stamped proof of every submission and any mailed forms.
If you miss a deadline, appear in person immediately and document it.

summary: Florida is generally lifetime; meaningful relief usually requires court action on the conviction (vacatur/pardon) or specific statutory criteria.
watchOuts: Online removal from FDLE is limited; moving out of Florida does not remove your FDLE entry.
If denied, ask what documentation would change the outcome before re-submitting.
